componenttext: Good morning. My name is Erica, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the FMC Technologies Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Matt Seinsheimer, you may begin your conference.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies' Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statement issued yesterday can be found on our website.I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies' Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statement issued yesterday can be found on our website.
I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements made during this call. Although these forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations, beliefs and assumptions regarding future developments and business conditions, they are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by these statements.
Known material factors that could cause our actual results to differ from our projected results are described in our 10-K, 10-Q and other filings with the SEC. We wish to caution you not to place undue reliance on any forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date hereof.
We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any of our forward-looking statements after the date they are made, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the call over to John Gremp, FMC Technologies Chairman and CEO.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 conference call. On the call today is Maryann Mannen, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer, who is joining us from another location. I'll focus my comm
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our fourth quarter 2015 conference call. On the call today is Maryann Mannen, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer, who is joining us from another location. I'll focus my comments today on 2015 performance and our market outlook for the current year. Maryann will provide specifics on our quarterly and full year financial performance as well as our financial outlook for 2016. We'll then open up the call for your questions.
In 2015, global upstream spending declined approximately 25% as a result of falling commodity prices. North America markets were impacted greater than most, experiencing the steepest activity decline seen in nearly 3 decades. Clearly, this was a very challenging year for the energy industry.
FMC Technologies entered the downturn with solid operational momentum, and we responded early with aggressive restructuring actions across all of our businesses. This wasn't just a reaction to declining activity levels, it was a fundamental change in the way we manage our business, aimed at providing meaningful and sustainable cost savings. Our efforts focused on driving better execution, product and process standardization, innovative technology and integrated business models. These are important steps that we believe will put the company in an even stronger competitive position.
In 2015, we were able to deliver on several key metrics. In Subsea Technologies, margins increased for our fourth consecutive year. For the full year, excluding all restructuring charges, we achieved Subsea margins of 15.1%. The strong results were driven by the strength of our backlog and the continued trend of solid execution.
We also finished the year with $3.1 billion of inbound orders in our Subsea technology segment, achieving our full year target of at least $3 billion. For the quarter, our Subsea inbound orders totaled $490 million, which included the recently announced award for the Woodside Greater Western Flank Phase 2 project on the Northwest shelf of Australia. This was an important award from a long-standing alliance partner with deliveries expected to extend through 2018.
As we look forward, operators are now not only challenged to improve project economics, but the sharp decline in oil prices is limiting their capital spending plans. Customer priorities continue to evolve, but the message is clear. Operators are determined to live within their cash flows, putting the burden of balancing budgets on capital spending.
Although it's unlikely that today's commodity prices reflect the assumptions used for long-term project economics, royal oil prices do impact current cash flow. The increasing level of commodity price volatility creates even more uncertainty around these cash flows. And even though project economics are improving, the pace of large-scale developments will be driven by operator cash flow, and this is different than past cycles. But even in this more challenging environment, we have been successful in working with our customers to bring down costs and make projects economic. Our initiatives are working. The award for the Woodside Greater Western Flank Phase 2 project is a great example of this success. With this project, we adopted the same standard that had been used on a previous development and significantly reduced the project management and engineering hours. We also used existing tools to install and test the equipment. By using standard FMC specifications, we were able to reduce the inspection points by more than 50%. And finally, we leaned out the documentation process for additional savings. Much of this success came from the operator's willingness to accept a vendor-based approach versus the traditional client-specific requirements. 
As we think about our Subsea order potential for 2016, I want to talk about the major components that make up our Subsea inbound: services, small projects and large projects. Broadly speaking, we expect Subsea service orders to remain fairly resilient with only modest declines driven by the level of installation work. We expect a somewhat lower level of order activity for smaller projects in 2016. These projects are not immune to spending reductions, but they typically have lower cash outlays and can provide operators with a relatively quick payback. Now forecasting order levels for larger projects is a challenge in the current environment. There are a number of large projects that we're tracking, and we do see the potential for some of these projects to be awarded in the current year. However, we don't foresee any $0.5 billion to $1 billion megaprojects being awarded this year, and that will make it difficult for us to match the level of Subsea orders that we received in 2015.
Despite the Subsea order uncertainty, we as a company remain focused on our initiatives to improve deepwater project economics. We also believe that we can do even more with our integrated business models, and that's what we're doing with our Forsys Subsea joint venture with Technip. Earlier this week, the joint venture announced the award of another integrated FEED contract, this one from Statoil for the development of their tray sac  field. We are encouraged by Statoil's willingness to adopt a different business model. The Forsys Subsea approach is gaining traction and tray sac is an important example of that progress.
Our Subsea business cost structure, we believe, has the potential for significant savings. Specifically we're focused on optimizing our global manufacturing operations, standardizing our processes and product offerings and further integrating our global supply chain. These actions will provide sustainable structural benefits that will ensure that we retain, if not improve, our cost advantage. At the same time, we will preserve our core engineering and project management capabilities. Further, we will continue to invest in new technologies and expand our customer relationships. Collectively, these actions will strengthen our Subsea business and ensure that we're prepared for an eventual market recovery.
Let me now turn to our Surface Technologies segment. Revenues for the quarter were down 12% sequentially. However, once we adjust for all charges, we closed out the quarter with an adjusted margin just above 10% despite the severe activity declines posted throughout North America in 2015. Activity levels for our international surface wellhead business held up sequentially, but we're seeing the impact of pricing pressure as a result of the deteriorating global market. We expect activity levels outside of North America to remain resilient in 2016. We moved aggressively to streamline our North America business, and our actions have been focused on more than just responding to the lower activity levels. We're approaching this market in a fundamentally different way. We restructured our management organization, consolidated our service lines and integrated our products and service offering. These actions will create greater efficiencies and drive better operational performance, and they'll further improve our position in the North America onshore market. This approach has been a key driver in expanding our customer base and resulting in new contract awards. 
Let me end with 2 main points. First, deepwater operators were behaving differently in this current cycle. Cash flow and uncertainty are affecting near-term decisions. But we are making an impact on deepwater project economics. We're driving cost lower and reducing operator risk through product standardization, new technologies and new business models. The Woodside Greater Western Flank and Statoil tray sac projects are 2 tangible examples of our success. Second, we are intensely focused on what we can control, taking aggressive actions across the entire company. Most importantly, our restructuring activities go beyond workforce and facility reductions. We're using the downturn as a catalyst to fundamentally change the way we manage our organization so that we can sustainably deliver our products and services in an effective and cost-efficient manner regardless of the market conditions. Maryann will now take you through the financial details in the quarter and for the full year and provide a more detailed explanation of our 2016 expectations.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our fourth quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.46 when excluding certain charges of $73 million or $0.22 per diluted share incurred in the quarter. As we indicated last quarter, we took further restructuring actions in the fourth quar
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our fourth quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.46 when excluding certain charges of $73 million or $0.22 per diluted share incurred in the quarter. As we indicated last quarter, we took further restructuring actions in the fourth quarter. Included in our reported results are pretax charges of $31 million for restructuring actions or $0.10 per diluted share. Also included in the quarterly results are pretax inventory adjustments of $42 million due to the prolonged lower activity levels in North America. 
The inventory write-downs include a $36 million charge in our surface technology segment. The remaining $6 million was recorded in our Energy Infrastructure segment. These inventory adjustments reduced our reported earnings by $0.12 per diluted share. We have provided a schedule in our press release issued last evening to show the quarterly and full year impact of these costs incurred. 
Looking at the full year, we undertook a significant amount of restructuring in response to the decline in market activity in North America as well as the forecast reductions for 2016 in our Subsea business. The combined charges in 2015 for restructuring and other severance as well as impairments totaled $132 million before tax. In the surface technology segment, we incurred $74 million of charges for restructuring our facilities, impairment of assets and headcount reductions. We expect these actions to have benefit in 2016 as we operate on a lower cost base and in a lower rig count environment. In our Subsea technology segment, we incurred $50 million of charges, primarily for headcount reduction taken in the second half of the year. Activity levels remain strong in this segment through the first 3 quarters of 2015. Energy Infrastructure incurred $8 million for restructuring. This occurred mainly in the measurement solutions business where the low North American activity levels reduced market opportunities. Collectively, these actions will further strengthen our operating performance as we manage through the soft market conditions we expect will continue throughout 2016 both in North America as well as in our Subsea business. When adjusting for our restructuring and impairment costs including inventory write-downs of $49 million, full year EPS was $2.27 for 2015. 
Moving to our operating segments. Subsea Technologies revenue in the quarter was $1 billion. Quarter-over-quarter revenue comparisons were negatively impacted by $134 million of foreign currency translations. Lower subsea services activity, primarily intervention services as well as lower project activity, contributed to the quarter-over-quarter results. Subsea Technologies operating profit was $132 million in the quarter, excluding restructuring and other severance and impairment charges of $25 million. Quarter-over-quarter profit comparisons were negatively impacted by $15 million of foreign currency translations due to the strong U.S. dollar. Operating margins in the quarter were 12.9% excluding restructuring and other severance and impairment charges. Excluding all charges and the impact of foreign currency translation, operating profit was down approximately 29% quarter-over-quarter. The decline was driven primarily by the lower revenue, reduced well intervention activities in the North Sea and higher research and development expense due to the timing of expenditures. We experienced headwinds from the strengthening U.S. dollar throughout the year.
For the full year, Subsea revenue included $540 million of unfavorable impact and operating profit included $77 million of unfavorable impact due to the strong U.S. dollar. Full year Subsea margins excluding restructuring and impairment charges were 15.1%, consistent with our estimates throughout the year as our project execution continue to support solid operating margins. We began significant headcount reductions in the second half of 2015 as project volumes began to weaken. We expect to take further actions in the first quarter of this year. These actions and continued strong operational performance will support us as our Subsea volumes decline from 2015 levels. Segment backlog exiting this quarter was $3.8 billion. This compares to prior year backlog of $5.8 billion. Some of this backlog has a longer delivery horizon and will be recognized over the next 3 years. 
Moving to our Surface Technologies results. Surface Technologies reporting an operating loss for the fourth quarter of $7 million, including restructuring and other severance impairment charges of $3 million. When excluding the severance, restructuring and impairment charges as well as the inventory adjustments, we posted operating profit of $32 million and an operating margin of 10.1% in the quarter. As was mentioned earlier, we had significant inventory adjustments that impacted our Surface Technologies segment. During the quarter, we took a write-down of $36 million for inventory. Most of the write-down was related to our North American businesses where sharp activity declined, drove significant reduction to future demand estimates for the region. However, the underlying results represent the continued decline in activity in our North America business. Operational profit performance was supported by the benefit of the restructuring efforts made throughout the year. In some international regions though, activity levels have proven to be more resilient. However, as we noted last quarter, our operating results now reflect pricing challenges across all major geographies, including our surface wellhead business outside North America. 
We have taken significant restructuring actions in our Surface Technologies business. These actions focus both on reducing our operating cost structure in North America and restructuring the business model to deliver an integrated product offering intended to bring greater value to our customers. On a full year basis, our operating margins were 11.8% when excluding restructuring, impairment and inventory charges, reflecting the benefit of restructuring activities taken earlier in the year. While we expect the weak activity levels in North America to persist throughout 2016, these actions will further improve our operating competitiveness through our significant workforce reductions and implementation of our integrated product offering. Segment backlog stands at $433 million. This continues to predominantly be reflective of our surface wellhead business outside of North America. 
Moving to Energy Infrastructure. Revenue for the fourth quarter was $96 million. The segment reported operating losses of $3 million, including $4 million or restructuring and other severance charges. Additionally, we incurred charges of $6 million in the quarter for the write-down of inventory of our measurement solution business due to lack of demand from weak activity. Segment results continue to be negatively impacted by the sharp activity decline in the North America market.
Let's turn to the corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $15 million. Other revenue and expense net reflects expense of $23 million. The majority of expense relates to foreign currency losses, primarily associated with the currency devaluation of the Angolan kwanza. Our fourth quarter tax rate was negative 8.7%, due in part to a favorable shift in geographic earnings mix and the reinstatement of a research and development tax credit enacted in late December. Our full year tax rate was 21.4% due in part to the lower mix of earnings subject to U.S. tax. Capital spending this quarter was $40 million. This brings our spending in 2015 to $251 million. We generated solid cash flow from operations of $932 million. At the end of the fourth quarter, we had net debt of $240 million. It is comprised of $960 million of cash and $1.2 billion of debt. We averaged 230 million diluted shares outstanding in the quarter. We repurchased 1.3 million shares of stock during the fourth quarter at an average cost of $31.23 per share. For the full year, we repurchased a total of 5.3 million shares for a total cost of $190.4 million.
Let me next discuss our outlook for 2016. We expect Energy Infrastructure revenue to be down by approximately 5% year-over-year. Revenue will continue to be negatively impacted by the weak North American market in our measurement solutions business. Therefore, we do not expect a recovery in this business this year. However, we do expect the benefits from prior year restructuring to favorably impact segment profitability in 2016. We expect full year margins in the high single digits. Given the recent rig count decline, Surface Technologies revenue is now expected to be down 15% to 20% from 2015 due to uncertain North American market activity. We are not assuming a recovery from current rig count levels. Full year operating margins are targeted at high single digits, excluding any restructuring charges that may be necessary. While we will benefit from the restructuring actions taken in 2015 and those forthcoming in 2016, pricing pressure in both our North American international business provides significant headwinds at these activity levels. Subsea revenue for the full year in 2016 should be approximately $3.6 billion. We expect revenue from our Subsea backlog of approximately $2.2 billion. For our subsea services business, we expect revenues of approximately $1.3 billion, down modestly from 2015. Startups of certain services are expected in April of this year with lower utilization expected than prior years. Given the lower visibility for inbound, as John has discussed, we are assuming a minimal amount of revenue from current year inbound. This would, therefore, be a source of upside to our 2016 revenues if inbound were stronger. We continue to expect Subsea margins in the range of 11% to 13%, excluding any restructuring charges that are likely in 2016. Further cost reductions will help offset the expected revenue decline. When combined with continued strong execution on our backlog, we see the potential to deliver margins above the midpoint of the guidance range. I'll now provide you with guidance on our corporate items. 
In 2016, we expect corporate expense to be approximately $15 million to $16 [ph] million per quarter. We expect other revenue and expense to be an expense of approximately $13 million to $14 million per quarter with a potential for further foreign currency fluctuation. We expect our 2016 full year tax rate to be between 23% and 25%. Our earnings subject to U.S. income tax are expected to be lower in 2016. We expect capital spending for the year of approximately $180 million. This represents a 28% reduction from 2015. This spending does not include any contingent capital that may be needed to respond to contract award. We do anticipate further restructuring will be necessary as the market activity provides better clarity on the impact in future periods. We will continue to provide guidance as we estimate the cost of benefits of these actions. 
Let me now close with the following comments. Given the latest move down in the U.S. rig count, our Surface Technologies segment performance has become more difficult to forecast. We're responding with additional headcount reduction as well as further facility consolidations and closures, our efforts in the last year to provide an integrated service offering should support our growth in this market recovers. In Subsea, we have a solid backlog to deliver the 2016 estimates provided albeit lower than in previous years. Our headcount reduction should partially offset the revenue decline forecast in 2016, and our project execution should allow us to deliver solid operating performance supporting operating margin guidance. As 2016 Subsea inbound develops, we are prepared to take further actions where needed. We are working to optimize our global footprint to deliver sustainable, superior performance now and when the deepwater and North American markets recover. While managing the company through extreme market uncertainty, we remain focused on preserving and further developing our technical capabilities and customer relationships and maintaining our market leadership. Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

componenttext: Just to start here. Thanks for the precise color here with regard to guidance on Subsea. You provided us with revenue the backlog guidance for 2016 and service revenue guidance. What were those in 2015? What was revenue out of backlog, what was the conversion ratio and what was the service component in 2015?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Our service numbers, I mentioned, service is down just slightly. So our service inbound and service revenues are essentially the same, and our service revenue just approached about $1.5 billion. We had some small revenue recognition from what we call
componenttext: Yes. Our service numbers, I mentioned, service is down just slightly. So our service inbound and service revenues are essentially the same, and our service revenue just approached about $1.5 billion. We had some small revenue recognition from what we call inbound, our book in turn, and the balance would have been from backlog. That backlog conversion ratio was about in the range of 60% [ph] for this year.

componenttext: Okay. And so we're implying with your guidance you're assuming something little bit less than that for 2016 with regard to the backlog conversion ratio?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John. Let's talk about where we last were. We had Subsea margin for 2016 range of 11% to 13%, previously about 4 months ago in the earnings call there was a bias towards the high end. We believe that margin range 11% to 13% is still valid, but the
componenttext: This is John. Let's talk about where we last were. We had Subsea margin for 2016 range of 11% to 13%, previously about 4 months ago in the earnings call there was a bias towards the high end. We believe that margin range 11% to 13% is still valid, but the bias towards the high end is not. Why? Because over the last 4 months we've seen a deterioration in, obviously, in oil prices in the market. It's going, to some degree, affect revenues. Revenue declined in 2016, more so than we saw 4 months ago. And despite as Maryann mentioned, our efforts to restructure and reduced cost that's going to put some margin pressure. Further, as you know, the whole industry has been faced over the last couple of months of even more intense pricing pressures of the combination of those 2 things take us off of that earlier comment about being on the high end of that 11% to 13% range.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Ole Slorer from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Ole Slorer from Morgan Stanley.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The 11% to 13% margin guidance, that is still a very robust performance compared to what some of your peers are achieving and also pretty robust compared to some of your prior down cycle. So could you just give us a little bit more color on what makes you
componenttext: The 11% to 13% margin guidance, that is still a very robust performance compared to what some of your peers are achieving and also pretty robust compared to some of your prior down cycle. So could you just give us a little bit more color on what makes you confident that you can handle this down cycle in this way?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you know, most of our revenue from our company comes from Subsea revenue and backlog. Those margins on our backlog are fairly robust and strong. You couple that with the execution improvements that we've made over the 1.5 years and that holds up
componenttext: Well, as you know, most of our revenue from our company comes from Subsea revenue and backlog. Those margins on our backlog are fairly robust and strong. You couple that with the execution improvements that we've made over the 1.5 years and that holds up the margins now subsea services will be an important part of the revenue and we're working hard to protect those margins add to that the cost reduction that we've been implementing really ahead of the downturn. I think that's kind of important. When you think about prior downturns, we had that big Subsea backlog, we may have been a little delete in taking action. That's not the case this time. We're acting -- when you think about it, Subsea revenues in 2015, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, are only down 5%, yet we have been taking restructuring actions well in advance of that activity downturn. So I think the cost reduction actions that we've taken quickly and aggressively, the quality of our margins and backlog for Subsea and our good work in holding up the Subsea services activity is what's contributing to what you're referring to as robust margins.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you look a little bit further out than this year, can you see -- nobody has a perfect vision of the future right here, it's pretty blurry. But assuming that this is a normal cycle at some point back into this year or the stock is coming back again
componenttext: Yes, if you look a little bit further out than this year, can you see -- nobody has a perfect vision of the future right here, it's pretty blurry. But assuming that this is a normal cycle at some point back into this year or the stock is coming back again, the cost pressures you highlighted are real. Your mix is changing a little bit. Do you think you can manage to this entire cycle with the margins in double digits for this division?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's certainly our intent, Ole. In my prepared remarks, you heard about the restructuring the steps that we're taking to protect our customer relationships and alliances. These are all intended to do that, but you're right. I mean we're facing ext
componenttext: Well, that's certainly our intent, Ole. In my prepared remarks, you heard about the restructuring the steps that we're taking to protect our customer relationships and alliances. These are all intended to do that, but you're right. I mean we're facing extraordinary unprecedented headwinds with this downturn in the industry, so it is hard to predict. Again, I referred to the pricing pressure that we're under, the project delays, the lower level of revenue. This all put pressure on margins, but we're taking a lot of action in a sustainable way to try to protect those.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Rob Mackenzie from Iberia Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Rob Mackenzie from Iberia Capital.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for you guys. Coming back to your prepared comments, I think, John, you mentioned that operators were willing to talk more with vendor-based approach, and you highlighted some of the cost savings you guys have been able to achieve. At what poin
componenttext: A question for you guys. Coming back to your prepared comments, I think, John, you mentioned that operators were willing to talk more with vendor-based approach, and you highlighted some of the cost savings you guys have been able to achieve. At what point do you think the operator start looking at that and saying, "You know what, now's the time to intent to commit for a multi-decade project versus just looking purely at more of a cash flow-based approached by these big operators.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, that's a good question. In today's environment, it's so hard to predict when that is because I said in my prepared remarks, this cycle is so different. In the past, capital budgets may be reduced and fixed emphasis is improving our project economics
componenttext: Rob, that's a good question. In today's environment, it's so hard to predict when that is because I said in my prepared remarks, this cycle is so different. In the past, capital budgets may be reduced and fixed emphasis is improving our project economics once the're improved at the hurdle rates had a pretty good chance of that project going forward that's all changed now. Even though project economics of an improved -- I was in Norway last week, and Statoil has made remarkable progress in part to reduced breakeven of major projects from $70 a barrel to $40 a barrel, and there's a lot more that we can do. But even when you improve project economics, it doesn't mean the project will go ahead because the restrictions on cash flow, which is driven by the current oil price. But you're right. At some point, as we continue to improve project economics and cash flow hopefully will start to improve that the operators will realize the importance of green lighting some of these projects and taking the steps to develop these deepwater fields for the purpose of replacing production in future years. I think that we'll have to look at the cycle differently, and we have to take into account the importance of cash flow as they approve those projects.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And my related follow-up is with the queue off development projects out there, how long can we have basically no exploration work and still support kind of current activity levels that you're guiding to in 2016? Just off development projects.
componenttext: And my related follow-up is with the queue off development projects out there, how long can we have basically no exploration work and still support kind of current activity levels that you're guiding to in 2016? Just off development projects.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I've been -- that's a challenging question. We know -- I mean there's been lots of reports and analysis that says that severity of the capital reductions eventually leads to supply shortfalls, and that gap only grows and becomes more extreme as the c
componenttext: Yes, I've been -- that's a challenging question. We know -- I mean there's been lots of reports and analysis that says that severity of the capital reductions eventually leads to supply shortfalls, and that gap only grows and becomes more extreme as the capital spending reductions continue. So I think everybody is aware that that's the ramifications and implications of severe capital spending reductions. When that will occur, it's hard to say.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of James West from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of James West from Evercore ISI.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, can you remind us just briefly how much of your Subsea order inbounds are services, small projects and the megaprojects, so we have an understanding what the baseline could be for 2016?
componenttext: John, can you remind us just briefly how much of your Subsea order inbounds are services, small projects and the megaprojects, so we have an understanding what the baseline could be for 2016?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fine, James. The service revenue last year was about, as Maryann pointed out, was just about $1.5 billion. Our run rate even in the fourth quarter generally supported, so we're looking at subsea services for 2016 inbounds somewhere 1 2, 1 3, 1 4 range. So
componenttext: Fine, James. The service revenue last year was about, as Maryann pointed out, was just about $1.5 billion. Our run rate even in the fourth quarter generally supported, so we're looking at subsea services for 2016 inbounds somewhere 1 2, 1 3, 1 4 range. So there'd be some slight headwinds but generally we believe for it to be resilient. The smaller projects, as we learned last year, are pretty lumpy. We had a really low level in the first quarter, fairly low level in the fourth quarter but strong small project inbound in the second and third quarter. Last year was just under about $0.5 billion. Obviously, with the downturn in the industry, some of those are going to come under pressure. And as I said in my prepared remarks, we'll be somewhere close to that because those projects, the capital requirements are a bit less. They have shorter paybacks. They're in the Gulf of Mexico where we have -- typically where we have a stronger position, so we think the smaller projects will be somewhere in that range may be a little bit less it's the large projects that make up the difference and those are where a lot of the uncertainty in the industry are today, and that was really the basis of my remarks. Absent a significant number of large projects being awarded in 2016, we can't hit or match the same Subsea inbound number that we had in 2016. So it depend. We expect the couple of those to be awarded and are well positioned and that will be on top of the service and small project inbound orders that we're projecting for 2016.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016

I'm hopeful then. Is that mitigating some of the margin deterioration that we see so we typically see FMC 4Q to 1Q. What's your thoughts on margins for 1Q?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Bill. So you're right. As I mentioned on the call last than the Light Well Intervention utilization did come down in October, and we expect that to continue through the first quarter. So that step-down has largely happened. However, we are taki
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Bill. So you're right. As I mentioned on the call last than the Light Well Intervention utilization did come down in October, and we expect that to continue through the first quarter. So that step-down has largely happened. However, we are taking a volume decline right, as you heard from comments on the full year, we will take a step down in volume in Q1. I do expect to see a sequential decline 4 to 1 as I have -- as we have previously with some similar characteristics in Q2, that will likely be our strongest quarter. And then as we come down the volume curves, 3 and 4, probably at a bit weaker. But yes, I do expect to see a sequential decline Q4 to Q1 again this year.

componenttextpreview: Just not the same as you've seen in past years?
componenttext: Just not the same as you've seen in past years?

componenttext: Yes, that's correct, Bill.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I guess, a question for you as it relates a large projects. I was curious, you mentioned in your prepared, is the fact that on the Greater Western Flank that was on an alliance partner. Maybe you could help us. Do you feel like you have better visib
componenttext: John, I guess, a question for you as it relates a large projects. I was curious, you mentioned in your prepared, is the fact that on the Greater Western Flank that was on an alliance partner. Maybe you could help us. Do you feel like you have better visibility in terms of us you guys at their try to handicap a projects could get led, which may not this year. Do you get better reads on the guys or more conviction around potential alliance customers in terms of better clarity on possible awards versus the non-alliance clients?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to make an initial remark, and then have Doug respond with some specifics. Clearly, with an alliance partner, we have visibility of their entire portfolio. We're engaged constantly on these projects and how to make we have much greater visibilit
componenttext: I'm going to make an initial remark, and then have Doug respond with some specifics. Clearly, with an alliance partner, we have visibility of their entire portfolio. We're engaged constantly on these projects and how to make we have much greater visibility on how those projects are going and where they are in the queue. But one of the things that makes it different in this cycle versus past cycles, even our alliance partners are uncertain about, which projects are actually going to go forward and which ones aren't because they are unsure of their cash flow requirements, which cash flow generated because that's changing constantly as oil prices change, so I would say even though we have more visibility with alliance partners the non-alliance partners, even in that context there's been more uncertainty and moving around and reprioritization of projects than what I've seen historically. But Doug has got some more specific experience on some projects and how they move around, so I'd like him to comment. Doug?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. If you allow me to look at maybe the next 12 to 15 months versus the calendar year, it's a mix of partner, non-partner projects, but we're certainly targeting a group of projects. If you kind the look of it geographically, starting in Africa pa
componenttext: Yes, Bill. If you allow me to look at maybe the next 12 to 15 months versus the calendar year, it's a mix of partner, non-partner projects, but we're certainly targeting a group of projects. If you kind the look of it geographically, starting in Africa particularly in East Africa as well as Angola, there's a series of projects that have been tendered, in some cases are being reworked in other cases are being reviewed at this time. Moving on to Australia, Again, some very strong partner accounts as well as some non-partner accounts in Australia and some activity that we could see coming out of that region as well. In the Gulf of Mexico, we've been tracking some large projects with partner accounts as well as, obviously, this is ground for where our partnerships pay off in some of the smaller orders. And then, finally, in the North Sea, we announced recently the Johan Sverdrup award from Statoil, we -- the Forsys Subsea put on the press release on tray sac. So we're pretty excited about some of the activity that's going on in the North Sea with Statoil as well as other independent operators.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Jud Bailey from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Jud Bailey from Wells Fargo.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question on the surface guidance. Maryanne, I think you indicated your expectation was for revenue to be down about 15% to 20%. Just wanted if you could give us a little bit of color on what your assumption is for maybe U.S. rig count or
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question on the surface guidance. Maryanne, I think you indicated your expectation was for revenue to be down about 15% to 20%. Just wanted if you could give us a little bit of color on what your assumption is for maybe U.S. rig count or U.S. spending to help us think about how to think about what your expectation is to get to that kind of revenue number it seems like most of the E&Ps are announcing our suggesting spending down as much as 50% or 40%. So just wanted to get a little bit of a better understanding on what's implied in your guidance for surface and what you assume the U.S. market.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jud. So the last few months, as you know, rig count North America has taken another leg down. We've taken a good look at that. We're assuming rig count kind of bounces around as level for the balance of the year, so somewhere in that range will abou
componenttext: Sure, Jud. So the last few months, as you know, rig count North America has taken another leg down. We've taken a good look at that. We're assuming rig count kind of bounces around as level for the balance of the year, so somewhere in that range will about 500 our assumptions lie for the balance of the year. And as I mentioned in my comments were not assuming that we see recovery throughout the year. Obviously, if that were to change, our forecast estimate would change. But again, we're assuming a fairly flat rig count bouncing around that level throughout 2016.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my follow-up is on just trying to think through some of the shifts in your work and your projects for your Subsea business and maybe Greater Western Flank as an example. You're helping your customers get cost down. You're doing more standar
componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up is on just trying to think through some of the shifts in your work and your projects for your Subsea business and maybe Greater Western Flank as an example. You're helping your customers get cost down. You're doing more standardization. You're helping them lower their cost. Can you help us think about the margin opportunity for FMC for some of the new orders relative to maybe where your backlog is. I understand obviously that pricing, but it seems you're using less engineering hours. So is there a way to think about how margins would be for some of these projects you're discussing now relative to what you reported in 2015 or what's in current backlog?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Jud, the bottom of every cycle, there's been pricing pressure reflected in margins. We shouldn't expect this cycle to be any different. I think what we're trying to articulate is to improve project economics requires not incremental reductions in co
componenttext: Well, Jud, the bottom of every cycle, there's been pricing pressure reflected in margins. We shouldn't expect this cycle to be any different. I think what we're trying to articulate is to improve project economics requires not incremental reductions in cost but significant and sustainable reductions in cost, which is what we are focused on because the challenge for the entire industry when oil prices were much differently than they are today was to improve economics. We know that improving execution on these major projects is critical to improving project economics. We know the industry has not adopted low-cost standards, which now we see as an opportunity to push even harder, and we see examples as I related on the Greater Western Flank for more standardization. We also believe that technology can contribute significantly to reducing cost, and we're investing in that. And then finally, these new business models, which I think is represented again by the tray sac award and the willingness of a very progressive and successful company like Statoil willing to consider and adopt an entirely different business model for the purpose of a step change in project cost. Despite all that, we know that there'll still be some pricing pressure that will find its way of margins. Every cycle has been that way. We want to mitigate that by improving our cost position, and we think we can do that. Now where that settles out, we're going to have to see. But I think it's just go by past cycles, there's been pressure on margins as a result of pricing, and we should assume that's going to be the case again.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Scott Gruber with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Scott Gruber with Citigroup.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John or Maryanne, your cash balance is now at over $900 million in free cash flow positive this year. Is the current strategy keep building that cash balance to start the year or is it time to take a look at accelerating the buyback?
componenttext: John or Maryanne, your cash balance is now at over $900 million in free cash flow positive this year. Is the current strategy keep building that cash balance to start the year or is it time to take a look at accelerating the buyback?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been working diligently to ensure that we have that. Share repurchase continues to be a viable strategy for us, and you can see we repurchased in the fourth quarter. But in this environment, of course, we will be cautious. We will continue to evalua
componenttext: We've been working diligently to ensure that we have that. Share repurchase continues to be a viable strategy for us, and you can see we repurchased in the fourth quarter. But in this environment, of course, we will be cautious. We will continue to evaluate market conditions, we'll continue to evaluate our cash flow and be sure that we are providing the optimal utilization at the greatest return we can for the shareholders. But again, share repurchase will continue to be a viable strategy for us.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That makes sense. If there are some green shoots in the marketplace, would first use of that cash accelerate the buyback? And if so, what markers are you looking for in the marketplace?
componenttext: That makes sense. If there are some green shoots in the marketplace, would first use of that cash accelerate the buyback? And if so, what markers are you looking for in the marketplace?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you know, certainly, we believe that this valuation, our stock is undervalued. We believe in the long-term opportunities set for deepwater. We are positioning our company, as you can hear from both John's comments, Doug's comments and mine a
componenttext: Well, I think you know, certainly, we believe that this valuation, our stock is undervalued. We believe in the long-term opportunities set for deepwater. We are positioning our company, as you can hear from both John's comments, Doug's comments and mine as well, that we are positioning the company to be able to capitalize on the deepwater market and the North American market, so we obviously believe there are green shoots and we will be sure that we have the capability and the liquidity and the capacity to be able to respond to those green shoots when we see them. Clearly, commodity price is one of them. Our ability to achieve the cost reduction initiatives, as you've heard both John and Doug talk about, with respect to our business model changes both in Subsea and surface, will clearly present those triggers, if you will, that you represent for us to respond, and we stand ready to be able to do that.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Kurt Hallead from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Kurt Hallead from RBC.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just want to go back around one more time just on the Subsea dynamic. You've given a lot of good color around that. I know there's a lot of uncertainty out there, but would you -- in the way that you're maybe thinking of the world for 2016, would a 3
componenttext: So I just want to go back around one more time just on the Subsea dynamic. You've given a lot of good color around that. I know there's a lot of uncertainty out there, but would you -- in the way that you're maybe thinking of the world for 2016, would a 30% to 50% reduction in Subsea orders, in aggregate, kind of fit with the way you're looking at the world?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean Qwest has new numbers. Everybody has new numbers. As I said, the issue is going to be around large projects. We don't see any megaprojects on the horizon. So in the past, when you had a significant uptick in deepwater awards, it was usually be
componenttext: Yes. I mean Qwest has new numbers. Everybody has new numbers. As I said, the issue is going to be around large projects. We don't see any megaprojects on the horizon. So in the past, when you had a significant uptick in deepwater awards, it was usually because there were a couple of billion dollar projects that were awarded. Those aren't even on the radar screen. We have a list of projects that are being tracked, but the ability for those projects to get through the cash flow hurdles and make it into 2016 is limited. Some of them will be awarded but probably not all of them, and that speaks to a pretty significant maybe reduction in Subsea awards, maybe in the order of magnitude that you described versus prior years.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes in the line of David Anderson from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes in the line of David Anderson from Barclays.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, just a question on the surface business. Decrementals pretty good this quarter. Just curious how much that business is international? And also, can you just let us know where you stay on the layering and fullback integration you talked and the strike
componenttext: Yes, just a question on the surface business. Decrementals pretty good this quarter. Just curious how much that business is international? And also, can you just let us know where you stay on the layering and fullback integration you talked and the strike to figure out how those 2 components worked within the decrementals and how much is left do you think on the kind of delayering side?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Doug take the question on restructuring and delayering and our progress on really streamlining and leaning out our organization structure. Doug?
componenttext: I'll let Doug take the question on restructuring and delayering and our progress on really streamlining and leaning out our organization structure. Doug?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to say we're in the early innings of the process, I think, is fair. We've been fairly aggressive and got out in front in terms of the overall reductions. And I think that's what you're seeing in the decrementals and will continue to do so. But I t
componenttext: Yes. So to say we're in the early innings of the process, I think, is fair. We've been fairly aggressive and got out in front in terms of the overall reductions. And I think that's what you're seeing in the decrementals and will continue to do so. But I think there's a significant upside still to be realized in the value of our commercial offering in the surface integrated solutions business that we put together. It's a unique integrated offering that provides significant value to our customers. The adoption rate has been -- we've been pleased with the adoption rate, but this is only a few months old. So we see even more upside from the adoption of the new commercial model. In terms of the headcount reductions and delayering, that's something we got out early and will continue to stay in front of it.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So assuming international activity levels continue to hold up like you had talked about in 2016 and these other initiatives, do you feel confident that you can keep the decrementals in this territory through '16?
componenttext: So assuming international activity levels continue to hold up like you had talked about in 2016 and these other initiatives, do you feel confident that you can keep the decrementals in this territory through '16?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, similar to how John answered your earlier question on Subsea, that is absolutely our intention.
componenttext: Again, similar to how John answered your earlier question on Subsea, that is absolutely our intention.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Robin Shoemaker from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Robin Shoemaker from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maryanne, I just wanted to clarify on -- you previously talked about, apart from revenue out of backlog, customer support and book in turn. We're talking about subsea services revenue for the guidance. Does this that include customer support book in turn
componenttext: Maryanne, I just wanted to clarify on -- you previously talked about, apart from revenue out of backlog, customer support and book in turn. We're talking about subsea services revenue for the guidance. Does this that include customer support book in turn as previously described it?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me try to be clear. We typically talk about 3, if you will, revenue streams. One is obviously what comes from our backlog. The second being what we call subsea services. And again, just to reiterate, we do not backlog our Subsea services. So our
componenttext: Yes, let me try to be clear. We typically talk about 3, if you will, revenue streams. One is obviously what comes from our backlog. The second being what we call subsea services. And again, just to reiterate, we do not backlog our Subsea services. So our inbound and our revenue are typically very closely matched. We got a pretty small amount in backlog. And then the last would be our ability to recognize revenue from current inbound. We call that book and turn. So for 2016, what I have said is we're expecting very little to be able to book and turn to be able to achieve our 2016 inbound just simply because of the variability that's happening on that inbound number as John mentioned. To the extent that, that develops greater or more rapidly, then that could be an upside for us for 2016.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for clarifying that. My other question had to do with these very considerable cost savings, restructuring steps you're taking that in response to the downturn, especially in Subsea. In past peak cycles, we were kind of accustomed to seeing yo
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for clarifying that. My other question had to do with these very considerable cost savings, restructuring steps you're taking that in response to the downturn, especially in Subsea. In past peak cycles, we were kind of accustomed to seeing your margins in the 14%, 15% range. So if I know that a lot of your cost-cutting here is -- will deliver some benefits in the next upturn, but I wonder if you have any kind of order of magnitude in terms of margin basis points from this current program of restructuring that you think can be sustained when the business cycle improves.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually very excited about our ability to restructure, particularly in the Subsea side, but also in the surface side for that matter to restructure our organization to deliver the same high level of execution that we delivered over the last 2 years
componenttext: We're actually very excited about our ability to restructure, particularly in the Subsea side, but also in the surface side for that matter to restructure our organization to deliver the same high level of execution that we delivered over the last 2 years but doing it in a much more this efficient way and doing it in a way that's sustainable even when the market comes back. Now to put a margin percent on that, I think as Doug pointed out, is still early days. But we want to point out that a lot of the steps that we're taking are not just in response to lower activity that they are in fact sustainable. Where does that come from? Over the course of the last 3 or 4 years, we've made significant progress in globalizing our manufacturing organization, creating global standards. Today, we make a Subsea Christmas tree in many locations, but we make it the exact same way. That didn't exist 5 and 10 years ago. So we're in a position now where through standard practices and process, we can level low throughout the world. We can reduce our facilities yet still keep our footprint, yet still keep our ability to execute at a high level. So that's an important example of how are permanently reducing our cost. We've been able to delayer our organization quite frankly where there because of our struggles with execution because of the rapid growth. Now that we have a more normal or expect a more normal growth cycle, and our execution has improved, we don't need the same level of structure so as a result, we're confident that we can essentially lean out our organization in a way that is sustainable and permanent. Now we haven't put a number on it because we want to be we wanted to be honest, Robin you want to see it before we start putting a number on it, but we're very encouraged by the subsequent taking and the impacts will having a long-term cost structure of our company even in the market recovery.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of from Goldman Sachs.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, you mentioned the Statoil being able to bring down the economic hurdle rate very close to 40%. But as you look at your pipeline of projects that you're pursuing, where do you think the breakeven is? And I understand that you mentioned the issue is m
componenttext: John, you mentioned the Statoil being able to bring down the economic hurdle rate very close to 40%. But as you look at your pipeline of projects that you're pursuing, where do you think the breakeven is? And I understand that you mentioned the issue is more cashless economics, but could you highlight what percentage of projects are in that $50 to $60 a barrel kind of hurdle rate?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Every project is different. But some of the announcements have been done by us, and others suggest that of the deepwater portfolio, if you can get a 25% to 30% reduction in the cost, something like 70% or so those become become economic. I'm sure that cha
componenttext: Every project is different. But some of the announcements have been done by us, and others suggest that of the deepwater portfolio, if you can get a 25% to 30% reduction in the cost, something like 70% or so those become become economic. I'm sure that changes the outlook for oil prices changes but the start though example, for example, the capital markets presentation last week, they show where they have a 70 -- the breakeven has been reduced, as you alluded to, to $70 to $40 on Johan Sverdup, which we were successful in working with Statoil on. We were able to reduce our cost at the Subsea equipment by something close to 40% for Johan Castberg. Statoil has put a target out there for further double-digit reductions in costs. So I think the point we would want to make is that fairly quickly now, the economics are improving because of the step change in cost of these projects. And Statoil, I think, is a good example of not only the progress they made for Johan Sverdrup, but the target they put in place for further reductions I think when you get down to those levels what Statoil did on Sverdrup and what they plan to do in Castberg, significant number of deepwater projects become economic and breakeven.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The final question comes the line of Darren Garcicia from KL Group.
componenttext: The final question comes the line of Darren Garcicia from KL Group.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get the new business model that there's more granular it is announced with Statoil when you talk about new business models what's changing? What are the mechanics of that, so we can really understand how your business is operating differently.
componenttext: I wanted to get the new business model that there's more granular it is announced with Statoil when you talk about new business models what's changing? What are the mechanics of that, so we can really understand how your business is operating differently.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to let Doug talk specifically, particularly about the tray sac  project and how that model looks different.
componenttext: I'm going to let Doug talk specifically, particularly about the tray sac  project and how that model looks different.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Darren. So again, we're taking an integrated approach where we're bringing together the capabilities of ourselves as an SBS provider as well as a leading serve provider Technip. So in the case of tray sac, we were able to engage early in the process,
componenttext: Yes, Darren. So again, we're taking an integrated approach where we're bringing together the capabilities of ourselves as an SBS provider as well as a leading serve provider Technip. So in the case of tray sac, we were able to engage early in the process, worked closely with Statoil to identify opportunities to simplify the field architecture and bring in some new technologies, although it's still early in terms of the technology, the integrated technology development. We were able to bring in some unique capabilities between ourselves and Technip to lower the cost and improve the overall project economics. On top of that, we take over the responsibility and the opportunity to do the joint planning, to work the schedule, to ensure deliverability and to further improve the project economics. So again, it's a combination of simplifying the architecture. Well, first of all, early engagement, through early engagement being able to simplify the architecture introduce new technologies and capabilities and then provide a full integrated solution, which allows the overall project economics to improve quite considerably.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you think about these components between architecture, the technology and, let's call it, the installation, do you think about the breakdown as may be what drove like overall cost savings? How would you bucket those 3 -- those 2 [ph] things that you ju
componenttext: As you think about these components between architecture, the technology and, let's call it, the installation, do you think about the breakdown as may be what drove like overall cost savings? How would you bucket those 3 -- those 2 [ph] things that you just mentioned?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's where the exciting opportunity lies. Because, again, in the case of integrated technology, proprietary integrated technology, it's very much in the early days. So we think that's going to increasingly provide a much larger component of the ov
componenttext: Well, that's where the exciting opportunity lies. Because, again, in the case of integrated technology, proprietary integrated technology, it's very much in the early days. So we think that's going to increasingly provide a much larger component of the overall cost savings. In this particular case, it was really the early engagement driving the simplified field of architecture and bringing together the unique capabilities of these 2 industry leaders. As we go forward, we would expect additional savings that we would expect the shift between the buckets, if you will, to move more towards unique technologies, which will allow us -- and it's not just an exchange of hardware. When we're looking at new technologies, looking through the joint venture and our alliance and focusing on things like installability, operability, serviceability over the life of the field. So it's looking at that full life of field cost and bringing together technology early in the process by that early engagement it's going to allow us to have even greater savings as you move forward.
