headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. With me today are Maryann Mannen, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer. I'll begin my comments today with highlights from the
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our first quarter 2016 earnings conference call. With me today are Maryann Mannen, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer. I'll begin my comments today with highlights from the quarter as well as provide some remarks on the deepwater market and our Subsea order outlook.
Maryann will provide specifics on our finance performance and update our financial outlook for 2016. We will then open up the call for questions.
Our first quarter results reflect both the challenge of our current market and our continued success in execution performance. For the first time in nearly 3 decades, FMC spending to settle began for second consecutive year. The North America land markets were impacted almost immediately and activity continued to decline into the first quarter.
Deepwater revenue as been supported by project backlog, but low orders are now beginning to impact our Subsea business. Despite the market challenges, we've made considerable progress in addressing the things that we control. We're driving operational success by improving execution and taking aggressive restructuring actions that permanently lower our costs.
The improvements are up most evident in our Subsea Technologies segment. We posted another solid performance this quarter, reporting margins of 13.1% when excluding charges. These are strong results of our business as revenues fell 25% over the last 12 months. Very good execution, restructuring savings were key drivers to deliver these solid margins. 
In our Surface Technologies segment we faced a much more difficult challenge. The average U.S. recount continue to decline in the quarter falling 23% sequentially. This hit our North America business much harder than we expected. We don't believe the current level -- low level of activity is sustainable. The timing and pace of recovery in North America landmark is, however, remains uncertain.
Compared to North America, our international surface business has been more resilient. And our results came in largely as expected. We continue to benefit from our geographic mix of business with relative strength coming from the Middle East and North African market where rig counts have held up and better than most other parts of the world.
Across all of our businesses, we will continue to take further restructuring actions to go beyond workforce and facility reductions. We are committed to delivering a global footprint that is more efficient and scalable and it can provide sustainable savings well into any market recovery.
I will pause my remarks on the quarterly results with the comment on the balance sheet. We continue to stay focused on preserving our financial strength and liquidity in these uncertain times. We generated cash flow from operations of $109 million in the quarter and we reduced our net debt to $209 million. 
Turning to the deepwater outlook. The industry significant reduction in capital spending will ultimately lead to a decline in global production that will drive oil prices higher. With oil higher oil prices, the combination of operators improved cash flows and a greater confidence in the market will move spending higher.
Shell investment will come first given the smaller commitment and faster payback, but will take more than Shell to fill the supply gap. There will be a need for both conventional and deepwater production to meet global demand.
But for deepwater to be a credible source of future supply, project economics must improve. For many operators, some of their best prospects can be found offshore, but they've been a challenged by poor returns. For the these returns to improve, the industry must realize significant and sustainable reductions in the cost of deepwater development. As we've seen the industry has demonstrated significant efficiency improvements and cost reductions in onshore and conventional shale. We believe that a similar transformation can occur in deepwater. But unlike shale, where most of the big savings and efficiencies have been achieved, we're still in the early innings for deepwater.
We're confident the industry can deliver these savings because of the rapid progress we're seeing on multiple fronts. First, operators themselves are changing their approach to deepwater development. For instance, the final design for BPs Mad Dog Phase II project will be substantially different than originally proposed. Significant savings will be realized by more closely matching infrastructure spend to the pace of field development.
And will not project-specific, Statoil highlighted their success and reducing project breakevens from $70 a barrel to $41 per barrel, with expectations to push that number even lower.
Achieving this level of savings required more than overhead and vendor price reductions. It required fundamental changes in their development approach. Two significant components of deepwater development costs are drilling and topside facilities. Together, these 2 can be as much as 2/3 of the cost of deepwater project. The cost of drilling has been particular impacted by the historic high level of day rates that will provide substantial savings as legacy contracts expire in the future. There are also many ways to reduce the cost of topside facilities. While we yet to see much of these savings so far, we think many of them will be sustainable.
In addition to these savings, our company is focused on reducing the cost of scope of our scope of supply. We know that we can severely reduce the cost of Subsea production equipment and installation through beater execution, product standardization, innovative technology and a new integrated business models. We're especially encouraged by the industry's early adoption of a differentiated business model that integrates the scope of both the subsea production system and the cope to our Forsys Subsea joint venture an alliance with Technip.
While we're confident improved evidence will lead to future deepwater development, the Subsea outlook in the near-term is being impacted by a aggressive cutbacks in spending from major projects. In the first quarter, our total Subsea orders of $346 million were driven largely by subsea services. This order level highlights the relative stability of our service business and supports our view that full year service orders should approximate $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion for the year. Our confidence in these service revenues is driven by our visibility around installation activity and our maintenance and repair work. Much of this work is funded by operating budgets, not capital budgets. These expenditures maximize production uptime and improve operator cash flows.
Small orders for subsea equipment were light in the quarter, but these orders are typically lumpy and never spread evenly throughout the year. We only expect to see a modest decline in small orders for the full year. These orders are typically tied the smaller projects that have lower capital costs and offer higher returns and accelerated cash paybacks. Over the next 24 months, we see the potential for nearly 20 large projects to move forward. Some large projects are considered strategic and could be awarded this year. But there is likelihood that even these projects could be pushed into 2017. And we still do not expect any projects in excess of $500 million to be sanctioned before the end of the year.
The full recovery of deepwater will come when cash flows move higher, project economics improve and operators gain confidence in the business outlook. In the meantime, subsea order activity will reflect subsea services small projects associated with tiebacks and opportunities and some large strategic projects.
Clearly, there are significant challenges our industry faces today. But at FMC Technologies, we remain focused on the things that we can control. We will continue to improve project execution to protect our margins and competitiveness. We will take further restructuring actions that both to the declining market and sustainably lower our costs. We'll remain focused on improving project economics through standardization, technology and integrated business models. And finally, we will preserve our unique customer partnerships to secure awards in this highly competitive market.
I'll now turn the call over to Marianne.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our first quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.22, when excluding certain charges of $48 million or $0.13 per diluted share. Included in our reported results, are pretax impairment and other charges of $36 million were $0.10 per dilute
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our first quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.22, when excluding certain charges of $48 million or $0.13 per diluted share. Included in our reported results, are pretax impairment and other charges of $36 million were $0.10 per diluted share. Restructuring and other severance charges of $12 million or $0.03 per diluted share.
The impairment charges were related to our North American business in our Surface Technologies segment. Further reduction and market activity have impacted our outlook for revenue and profitability of certain assets requiring a reduction in their carrying value.
We have provided a schedule in our press release, issued last evening to show the quarterly impact of all these costs incurred. We continue to take action to restructure our organization, both in response to reduce North American land activity as well as the outlook we have provided for lower revenues for our subsea business in 2016.
Our subsea technology segment delivered solid results in the quarter. Subsea Technologies revenues in the quarter was $864 million. Quarter-over-quarter revenue comparisons were negatively impacted by lower project activity as well as $57 million of foreign currency translation.
Subsea Technologies operating profit was $113 million in the quarter, with a margin of 13.1%, excluding restructuring and other severance and impairment and other charges of $4 million. Operating margins decreased 155 basis points quarter-over-quarter, when excluding charges for both periods, as revenues were down approximately 25%.
While down from the prior year quarter, solid operating margins were the results of strong project execution as well as the benefits of restructuring activity. Segment backlog, exiting this quarter, was $3.4 billion, which compares to a prior year backlog of $4.8 billion.
Moving to of our Surface Technologies results. Surface Technologies revenues for the quarter were $266 million, down 41% from the prior year quarter. The revenue decline was driven by the steep contraction in our North American business, somewhat mitigated by more moderate the decline in our international business. Geographic mix continues to provide some offset to the weak domestic market as rig declines have been more muted in international market, particularly in the Middle East.
Surface Technologies operating profit for the fourth quarter was $13 million, when excluding impairment and restructuring and other charges of $42 million. Margins in the quarter were 5%, when excluding these charges. We have taken significant restructuring actions in our Surface Technologies segment. These actions were based in part on a planning forecast for 2016, that assumed U.S. rig count would decline to a approximately 500 working rigs during the first quarter and then maintain that level for the remainder of the year. The actual rig count declined proved to be even more severe than we anticipated, declining 36% from year end levels, just 450 at quarter end. The rig count has since declined to 431 rigs as of the end of last week.
While we have made good progress in adjusting to the lower activity levels in North America, the severity of the recount decline will require us to take further action. However, these actions will be balanced against our need to preserve operational capabilities that can respond to the market recovery.
Segment results reflect this challenging market, but excluding charges, we remain profitable doing part to the benefits of our significant restructuring actions to date, as well as the relative strength of our international business. Segment backlog, exiting the quarter, stands at $429 million, this is predominantly related to our wellhead business outside of North America, which continues to show resilience.
Moving to our Energy Infrastructure results. Revenue for the quarter was $84 million, down 17% from the prior year quarter. We reported a minor loss in the period when excluding charges. The segment continues to be negatively impacted by lower oil prices. Our measurements solutions business has been most affected due to the contraction in energy-related infrastructure spend in our North American market.
Overall, we recorded $10 million of restructuring cost in our segment operating results during the first quarter. We expect to incur additional restructuring cost of approximately $25 million to $30 million in total over the coming quarters as further actions are taken primarily in our subsea's technology segment. These headcount reductions and other restructuring actions will be more significant than previous as our subsea activity levels are reduced.
Let's turn to the corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $14.3 million. We now expect to spend approximately $14 million to $15 million per quarter through the remainder of 2016. Other revenue and expense net reflects expense of $30 million.
Our first quarter expense is typically higher than the remaining three quarters of the year due to the amortization period for certain equity compensation awards made in the period. Results were also impacted by foreign exchange losses. In the quarter, we experienced further impact from the ongoing and Nigerian For the remaining quarters of 2016, we still expect that other revenue and expense will be an expense of a approximately $13 million to $14 million Pecora. This quarterly estimate remains subject to foreign currency fluctuation.
Our first quarter tax rate was 23.4%, which reflects the lower percentage of overall earnings subject to U.S. tax. We now anticipate our 2016 tax rate to be between 21% to 23% for the full year, given a mix of earnings. Capital spending this quarter was $35 million, primarily directed towards Subsea Technologies. We now expect capital spending in 2016 to be approximately $150 million. The spending does not include any contingent capital that may be needed to respond to a contract award.
We generated cash flow from operations of $109 million in the period. At the end of the first quarter, we had net debt of $210 million. It is comprised of $1 billion of cash and $1.2 billion of debt.
Net debt has been reduced by more than $1.2 billion from its peak in the first quarter of 2013, due largely to the strong operating cash flows of the country. We averaged 229 million diluted shares outstanding in the quarter. We repurchased 1.1 million shares of stock during the first quarter at an average cost of $25.58 per share.
Looking forward, we continue to expect full year subsea revenues to approach $3.6 billion, excluding the impact of foreign exchange, driven by a approximately $2.2 billion of backlog conversion and $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion of subsea service revenue. We remain confident in full year subsea margins in the range of 11% to 13% excluding charges as we continue to execute well on our backlog and realize further benefits from our restructuring actions.
Surface Technologies revenue is now likely to be down a approximately 25% to 30% versus 2015. North America activity has fallen more than expected and we're now basing are forecast on the assumption that the U.S. rig count remains near current levels through the end of the year.
We now expect operating margins in the low to mid-single digits for the full year, excluding charges. Energy Infrastructure revenue is now likely to be down 5% to 10% year-over-year as market activity continues to be negatively impacted by our may measurement solutions business. We now expect that operating margin should approximate low to mid-single digits for the year, excluding restructuring charges.
The first quarter results reflect the operational improvement we've made in our subsea business, as well as the challenges our Surface and Energy Infrastructure business face adjusting to the rapid pace of activity decline in North America. We have responded aggressively to the lower activity experienced in these markets. And as we indicated in our guidance, we are accelerating the pace of restructuring in the next few quarters in our Subsea Technologies segment. As John earlier discuss, this is not only at current production, but also structural changes to the global management of our operations.
We will continue to conservatively manage our balance sheet through these period of uncertainty. Our net debt was further reduced in the quarter, our liquidity remains robust. We lowered our guidance for capital expenditures in 2016 and we maintained flexibility to continue share repurchase as we have done consistently for many years.
Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, want to be careful about right now -- look  when I described my prepared remarks is that we're counting on the inbound coming from services that seems to be a resilient, that we saw that in the first quarter where the level of service inbound was ve
componenttext: Well, want to be careful about right now -- look  when I described my prepared remarks is that we're counting on the inbound coming from services that seems to be a resilient, that we saw that in the first quarter where the level of service inbound was very consistent with the guidance we're giving. And the next area we have also have some confidence is on the ones the smaller orders and is the smaller projects that as I said in my prepared remarks, that are the most questionable right now. When you look at those smaller projects, it makes sense that they would come from the Gulf of Mexico. And in fact, even the first quarter, although,, our small orders were a little bit light. The ones that we did yet, some of Gulf of Mexico. And it just makes sense, Sean, because the infrastructure is there. The tend to be smaller. The paybacks a faster. So as we look forward at the smaller projects, it wouldn't surprise that at all, that those are going to -- not all, a number of come from the Gulf of Mexico. That certainly what we've seen historically, and I think this will be the case this year as well.

componenttextpreview: Well, let me tell you, let, the kinds of restructuring that we are referring to, obviously, we're doing some restructuring just to contact our capacity in light of the market. But the restructuring that we believe is going to be more sustainable, is the r
componenttext: Well, let me tell you, let, the kinds of restructuring that we are referring to, obviously, we're doing some restructuring just to contact our capacity in light of the market. But the restructuring that we believe is going to be more sustainable, is the restructuring that we're taking by the leaning out, particularly our manufacturing organizations as a result of improved execution. When we are executing better, we don't need the same structure to maintain our -- to deal with our performance. So we're in a position now, where lot of the restructuring is about delayering, it's about winning of the organization. Again, something we can now do because of our execution improvements. The other thing we're doing is we're doing more consolidation because of standardization. We can consolidate our manufacturing in fewer locations. Again, an example of restructuring that is sustainable cost reduction.

componenttext: Maryann, yes, certainly from a 2017 perspective as we mentioned before, it is our intent to be able to maintain those double-digit margins in to '17. So yes, I think, that's a reasonable price for us to be thinking about.

componenttextpreview: Several years ago, Michael, we consolidated all of our supply chain to come at a globally. Sort for a couple of years, our procurements has been done in an aggregate of global fashion. We've got a lot of benefits from that. We've also done low-cost countr
componenttext: Several years ago, Michael, we consolidated all of our supply chain to come at a globally. Sort for a couple of years, our procurements has been done in an aggregate of global fashion. We've got a lot of benefits from that. We've also done low-cost country sourcing. So I would say, we're not done yet, but we are pretty mature on the progressive supply chain strategy. And we did that consolidation, globalization of our supply chain several years ago. So I think, we're well into that. We will see obviously, in today's economic, we're seeing improvements in supply chain cost as a result of the downturn in industry. But in terms of significant gains through consolidation, we've been experiencing that over the last couple of years.

componenttextpreview: Well, Bill, that competitive environment that we're in now, we're in a tremendous pricing pressure from all of our partners. So, I can't think of a single partner we haven't had a serious discussion about our pricing levels and service. Now offsetting tha
componenttext: Well, Bill, that competitive environment that we're in now, we're in a tremendous pricing pressure from all of our partners. So, I can't think of a single partner we haven't had a serious discussion about our pricing levels and service. Now offsetting that, is we've made a lot of investments in service, we've done some reorganization, we've done our leading out. Our service continues to improve. And all these things help mitigate the effects of a lot of pricing pressure on service. I think I mentioned this and Maryann, in previous calls, we expect some margin erosion and services as a result of this downturn. But we also believe, that we can push back on a lot of it to the efficiency improvements we're making. So I would say, a modest margin pressure is a result of the downturn, but we've got cost partially offset that.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, the caution with subsea margins overall. Maryann, you touched on 2017. I didn't quite retain what you were saying. So maybe kind of taken from the standpoint. One, I get the retention of the original kind of margin forecast in terms of
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, the caution with subsea margins overall. Maryann, you touched on 2017. I didn't quite retain what you were saying. So maybe kind of taken from the standpoint. One, I get the retention of the original kind of margin forecast in terms of the range. I'd be curious with regard to the path. In light of the meager inbound it's coming this year for the balance of this year, likely, what does that set up with regard to sit likely scenario for 2017 conceptually?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure Bill. Yes, we're maintaining the 11% to 13% as we have, I mentioned earlier. It doesn't require us to get us a significant amount of inbound this year. So most of that margin, as it relates to the project, is already our backlog. And then, secon
componenttext: Yes, sure Bill. Yes, we're maintaining the 11% to 13% as we have, I mentioned earlier. It doesn't require us to get us a significant amount of inbound this year. So most of that margin, as it relates to the project, is already our backlog. And then, secondarily, John just addressed the question with respect to services. So assuming services hold up as we see, we feel very confident in our ability to execute 2016. As I also mentioned, over the next several quarters, remember our subsea service activity and our subsea project activity is being very strong. We have one of the strongest years in 2015 and we're still executing fairly large number of projects in 2015. As we get closer to the end of '16, of course, we begin to see those activity level tail off. So we are forecasting, as I mentioned in my comments, a relatively significant amount of reductions coming in the next three quarters to address that tailing off. Given our estimates for inbound, and given that benefit from those restructuring, again, we feel pretty confident in our ability to maintain double-digit margin going into 2017. A little bit difficult for me to give you an exact quarter-over-quarter as you can imagine, the timing and a mix of projects as they come through, will certainly impact that. But that's really the rationale for why we feel comfortable in the 11% to 13% this year and our ability to maintain double-digit going into '17.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it could be that, it could be other. There is a lot involved in service beyond light well intervention. So actually the money we spent had less to do with light and more to do with other service-related assets. But service is a critical part of our
componenttext: Well, it could be that, it could be other. There is a lot involved in service beyond light well intervention. So actually the money we spent had less to do with light and more to do with other service-related assets. But service is a critical part of our strategy. And it does require real assets that rent to the customer. That's what that was about. When it comes to leaning out the organization, it's less about machine tools and that sort of thing. Those investments where all made several years ago when we were growing. This is about a manufacturing strategy that allows us to standard Let me just give you 1 example, Jim. We manufacture subsea equipment in multiple regions to be close to our customers. That's strategy has served us well. But, we manufacture that equipment. The same equipment different in each geographic region. Today, we have 1 process, 1 assembly project, 1 machining process, and we do it in all the locations. And that's the kind of leaning out or savings that we are envisioning as opposed to big capital investments in machine tools. Quite frankly, because of the growth that we saw 3 years ago, the machine tools that we invested in then are state-of-the-art. So what I will talk about in terms of leaning out, is manufacturing processes, taking advantage of standardization, taking advantage of global practices, and really, leveraging our a good execution. Using for 8 quarters now, where we've had solid execution. You have seen in that margin. What changes is, that we are delivering on time. We don't need to build safety nets and other structure to overcome core execution yet. And we're just leveraging that and that's what's allowing us to lean out the organization and streamline the process.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So jim, as you will know, our surface business is quite broad in our offering. So it just depends on which portion of the business. But in speaking particularly to the North America market, there is the portion of our business that's more tied to the pres
componenttext: So jim, as you will know, our surface business is quite broad in our offering. So it just depends on which portion of the business. But in speaking particularly to the North America market, there is the portion of our business that's more tied to the pressure pumping industry and then there is our integrated offerings. So let me first talk about the pressure pumping industry. Clearly, as capacity comes backs in the market, it will require new equipment or new flowline equipment to be associated with that equipment. We talk about cannibalization in the industry. There is different type of cannibalization. Some, if you will, more severe than other. But in all cases, that treating out is not necessarily associated with the horsepower our with the unit. It's used as kit. And we are the largest provider of that. And we're the largest provider of inspection and repair services for that treating So we have a good idea and a very good understanding of the state of that equipment and the capacity that's in the market today. So we are confident that it does not require a significant pickup for us to be begin to see those orders flow more aggressively as that equipment will be needed to put that horsepower back into service. On our integrated offering, yes, increased activity, we'll certainly, benefit from that. But we're benefiting from the fact that we're changing our operating model and we're changing the commercial model by putting together the most offering on service to be able to help our customers most efficiently go from the last frac stage to selling of their commodity, if you will, to the point-of-sale. By being able to bring that together, we've actually been able to increase our market share even in this downmarket.

componenttextpreview: So, actually, what we've publicly announced was 3 integrated FEED studies. And we have activity actually beyond that. So let me just talk in general about the activity that we have experienced and where we are in terms of the conversion of those projects.
componenttext: So, actually, what we've publicly announced was 3 integrated FEED studies. And we have activity actually beyond that. So let me just talk in general about the activity that we have experienced and where we are in terms of the conversion of those projects. As we talked about when we first announced some of the original integrated FEED studies, some of them all the way back at the concept stage. And we said, though studies would take 9 to 12 months to complete, typically another 6 months plus or minus for the project to be sanctioned. So you are looking at anywhere from about 15- to 18-month cycle between the conception integrated FEED, all the way through the conversion the integrated EPCI or to the execution phase. On other projects, where we start pre-FEED or FEED, that cycle time is reduced by 3 to 6 months. We remain confident in the conversion of a project, and we had said in 2016, now for budgetary reasons, that may fall into the first quarter of 2017. But we certainly remain confident in the conversion from the integrated FEED to the integrated EPCI, as we're able to to our customers the significant savings by moving towards an integrated offering from the standalone SPS and offering.

componenttextpreview: David, in the subsea industry, it's pretty that once the project is sanctioned, that goes through FID. The projects Cohen get canceled. They are just too invested in. And we're pretty much seeing the same thing in this cycle. That doesn't mean that there
componenttext: David, in the subsea industry, it's pretty that once the project is sanctioned, that goes through FID. The projects Cohen get canceled. They are just too invested in. And we're pretty much seeing the same thing in this cycle. That doesn't mean that there aren't conversations around rescheduling. I think we've to that before, Petrobras, but even other customers are talk about rescheduling delivery dates. As I alluded to earlier, the pricing -- there is conversations about pricing on service. So these discussions are going on with virtually every one of our partners. But on the subject to cancellations, it's really just not typically in this industry once a projects gets through FID. Whether situations, whether there is raw material or inventory, then there are some discussions around possible cancellation, but by and large, those aren't material.

componenttextpreview: So, Dan, if you look at the M&A activity that we had in the last 6 or 7 acquisitions, every single one of those to support our strategy. We do have a clear strategy to grow and improve our market position in North America land business. Actually, our larg
componenttext: So, Dan, if you look at the M&A activity that we had in the last 6 or 7 acquisitions, every single one of those to support our strategy. We do have a clear strategy to grow and improve our market position in North America land business. Actually, our largest acquisition was Pure Energy, 3 years ago. That was to promote the integrated services and products directly to serve the North America market. So I think our historic M&A activity is very much in line with, not just general strategy, but our strategy of growing our market position -- improving our market vision and growing our market in North Africa lands. They aren't big gaps in our portfolio right now, but given the environment today, where there's opportunities to progress our strategies through acquisitions, we're certainly looking at it.

componenttext: That's right. Again, you look at our M&A history, and it's to expand the products and services and then integrate them, which is very different from a consolidation strategy. And one other things that wigging some real traction on in North America, is the idea of consolidating services and equipment from that last track to sort shale that hasn't been fully exploited. And the acquisition appear expansion of our product line, expansion of services. And then the integration of those capabilities creates real value for the operators and reduces lead time. So yes, you're right, the M&A is to fill the breadth of our services and products as opposed to say, consolidating other providers.

componenttextpreview: So, go back to the earlier commend we made about our strategy. And we have put together, is the most holistic offering and differentiated offering by integrating the aspects from the last frac, if you will, from the completion of the well all the way thro
componenttext: So, go back to the earlier commend we made about our strategy. And we have put together, is the most holistic offering and differentiated offering by integrating the aspects from the last frac, if you will, from the completion of the well all the way through the point-of-sale. And we really have forgotten significant traction in the market as a result of that. And it's not just the offering, but it is the ability then to change the commercial model, creating incremental value both for ourselves through market share, margin, as well as exposure to new customer base as well as creating value for our customers, by then being able to take was multiple interfaces, take it down to a single interface and be able to work with somebody. Much like others have integrated the subsurface, no one has been able to integrate the surface or at the breadth of products and services to be able to integrate the surface as we're now offering today. So we remain committed to that strategy. It allows us to work with multiple difference subsurface providers and being able to the for the customer to be able to have a most integrated package available to them.

componenttextpreview: No, the customer typically separates those 2 packages. They separate them for a variety of reasons. The subsurface typically goes through 1 department in the customer, if you will, one of their business lines, which is drilling and completions. And the su
componenttext: No, the customer typically separates those 2 packages. They separate them for a variety of reasons. The subsurface typically goes through 1 department in the customer, if you will, one of their business lines, which is drilling and completions. And the surface typically runs under the facilities group or the production part of the company. So that typically bid and they are more importantly, managed separately. And they have very different key performing factors in terms of success. And so because those are held agnostically between the 2 groups, within the customers organization, you're focused on a very different customers subset when you bring these -- what our offering compared the subsurface offering.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I outlined in my prepared remarks, the sequences go to go improved all price, better cash flow, confidence in the market, at the same time, we're seeing the project economics improve as a result of the fundamental changes the industry going through to
componenttext: As I outlined in my prepared remarks, the sequences go to go improved all price, better cash flow, confidence in the market, at the same time, we're seeing the project economics improve as a result of the fundamental changes the industry going through to make significant cost changes. When will that confidence show up? That's a little hard to predict. But your question is, where it show up first? As a laid out, even in the so-called services small projects you would think would move first because of the capital commitment is less and returns are generally better. Then you will see projects that are more strategic. There is another reason why that project needs to move forward. Maybe it's lease term. Maybe it's a national oil company that is important to that oil company to move out of the front. So you want to see large projects move for some other strategic reason. And then finally, it will go operator by operator. Where operators have a large portfolio of undeveloped deepwater discoveries. And when they look at their total portfolio and their need to raise production, and they will do that all in with the improving economics. Those are the project that will bubble up at the top. Now what will the price be, the breakeven price? Well, I alluded that -- shared that in my remarks. We're seeing substantial reductions in breakeven. I sited the Statoil number from $70 a barrel to $40 a barrel. And they think they continue to cut that even further. Deepwater breakevens across was a portfolio, it's a whole range of I don't think there is one particular magic number. But the sequence, of which projects will go first, I think the smaller projects first, then the strategic ones, and then it will depend on the portfolio that particular operator, which projects go. Doug, I'll let Doug make some additional comments.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, you talked about maybe some leading if you will weak signals. And one that I'd to is, up until this point, we've had -- we're in discussions on all these major projects as you would expect us to be working with our partners and with our clients to fi
componenttext: Yes, you talked about maybe some leading if you will weak signals. And one that I'd to is, up until this point, we've had -- we're in discussions on all these major projects as you would expect us to be working with our partners and with our clients to find ways to substantially reduce costs, reduce the breakeven levels, as John Over the past year, that conversation has been focused on cost. More recently, that conversation is shifted from cost to schedule and delivery. So we certainly see that as a positive weak signal when our customers are back to looking at not just cost as you always have, but looking at cost and delivery schedule because they are planning out there production and wanting to be able to back -- come back from when the need the production and when they need to place orders to be able to move these largest projects forward.

In terms of what's kind of going back to the drawing board, maybe to lower cost, because I think it's a pretty wide range what people think breakevens are. I think what percentage of projects probably come back to the table when cost them down, by and large? And then, a quick one on the back of that. s well, what is the lead time for orders on a project given your last comment?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think virtually every major project is being relooked at. I mean, I can't think of a single project that we're engaged in, that hasn't gone back to the drawing board. And why wouldn't it. Not only is the market allowing prices -- again prices to be reco
componenttext: I think virtually every major project is being relooked at. I mean, I can't think of a single project that we're engaged in, that hasn't gone back to the drawing board. And why wouldn't it. Not only is the market allowing prices -- again prices to be reconsidered. But all the things that we've been talking about in terms of fundamental change in the industry. Again, I can't think about a single project that hasn't been rereviewed. And I will let Doug talk about, specifically, about the lead times. Because I think we will see some real changes in lead times going forward.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's not just not bringing on the cost, John talked about earlier move into standardization, it's accepting industry best practices. We are now able to sit down with our clients and speaking in terms of delivery schedule by taking into account all those d
componenttext: It's not just not bringing on the cost, John talked about earlier move into standardization, it's accepting industry best practices. We are now able to sit down with our clients and speaking in terms of delivery schedule by taking into account all those difficult different aspects from standardization, technology, new models. We're talking delivery times that used to be 24 months being compressed down to 15-month time period.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on subsea services. Could you provide some color around bigger business buckets in that business? And what pieces have more resiliency versus some other?
componenttext: I wanted to touch on subsea services. Could you provide some color around bigger business buckets in that business? And what pieces have more resiliency versus some other?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the bucket start with installation services, where the original equipment mariculture are equipment installed by FMC Technologies. We have a backlog of equipment we're delivering. It has to be installed. Even some of what we've delivered, is in ou
componenttext: Yes, so the bucket start with installation services, where the original equipment mariculture are equipment installed by FMC Technologies. We have a backlog of equipment we're delivering. It has to be installed. Even some of what we've delivered, is in our customer inventory. It is yet to be installed. That's a fairly significant bucket, if you will, is services of new equipment. We're also seeing installation of refurbished equipment, which is another segment that is continuing to grow. That make sense. Operators that have got equipment. They would rather, in today's environment, would rather refurbish it rather than by buy equipment. Again, almost always goes back to the original equipment manufacturer and we're seeing our refurbished equipment, both the manufacturer, but it counts as service revenue and the installation of it, starting to grow. And then the third bucket, which we also expect to grow, is in maintaining production. So this is an existing production system that may need some maintenance, need to change other choker or control system. Operators in today's environment, they're not will spend that capital on new production. They are going to want to spend their operating expense or capital on maintaining the production they have. And so we expect that segment of the services market to grow, and again, typically you would call out the original equipment manufacturer to those installation services. And then finally, we have part of our service part of service growth strategy. First quarter, that revenue was balance fairly light. They are almost nonexistent. That comes back now, and subsequent quarters this year. So those are the primary buckets of subsea service, some of which we, you can see by my nature of my comments, we expect them to be fairly resilient. And in some cases, maybe a little bit of growth offsetting whatever reduction there might be in installation.

componenttext: Sure. So yes, in part, we're assuming that we will see some continued growth going into subsea services. But really the basis for that a and on maintaining margins, has to do with our ability to get the restructuring both from a headcount perspective as well as the comments that John and Doug talked about, in sort of reengineering, if you will, our footprint. What will allow us to, if you will, maintain or improve capacity on a much smaller footprint and in a much smaller cost base. So we'll be able to leverage all of the benefits of what we're taking in this year and next year, as those volumes begin to recover in the '17 and '18 timeframe.

componenttext: Certainly, Michael, there's an opportunity to do some alliances, particularly, when its comes if you will, several engineering type work. But we've rationally buildout, in your we built out the primary units on the train, if you will. And that was part of the acquisition strategy that we've had over the past few years as well as an organic new technology development strategy that's allowed us to come up with some very innovative technologies when it comes to increasing the performance of frac flowback as well as billing services as a result of being able to address some of the solid removable aspects of both of those service lines. So we're fairly confident that we have in place today, both from an organic as well as from our inorganic strategy over the last couple of years, the primary units to be able to exploit that value chain.

componenttext: Michael, you captured it appropriately. I will add one more element to that, it's changing the commercial model, right? Because when you put together an integrated offering, if it's simply some of the parts and you reduce a couple of headcount on location, sure, that's favorable, but that's not sustainable. We're looking for and sustainable change. So we're looking -- so what we're doing now, is with that offering in place, we've been able to over last year the value of that to our customers. And now, we're looking at new and innovative commercial models, again, to be able to create value both for ourselves as well as for our customers.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
